title: 113_hr1998
content: The Act may be cited as the "Big Cats and Public Safety Protection Act". Congress finds that the global illicit trade in wildlife is valued at up to $20 billion annually, with legal wildlife trade in the United States estimated at $2.8 billion annually. The illegal trade in prohibited wildlife species stimulates demand and expands illegal markets. Private possession, breeding, and sale of prohibited wildlife species have a detrimental effect on the health and welfare of the people in the United States and on species conservation. Private possession and breeding of prohibited wildlife species have a significant impact on interstate commerce, as these species are often used in public exhibitions, sold in the exotic pet trade, and transported across state lines. This activity also contributes to the illegal international wildlife trade, as prohibited species are difficult to control and differentiate once in private possession. Federal control of intrastate private possession and breeding of prohibited wildlife species is crucial for effectively regulating interstate trafficking. The US is a party to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora, aimed at protecting species from overexploitation through international trade. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In the Lacey Act Amendments of 1981, the definition of "breed" is expanded to include facilitating or failing to prevent reproduction of prohibited wildlife species. Additionally, a "traveling circus" is defined as an exhibitor holding a Class C license under the Animal Welfare Act. In the Consolidated Farm and Rural Development Act, section 349(a)(3) is amended by changing "section 2(a)" to "section 2(b)." Similarly, in the Lacey Act Amendments of 1981, various sections are amended by replacing "section 2(g)" with "section 2(h)" and "section 2(f)(2)(A)" with "section 2(g)(2)(A)." SEC. 4. PROHIBITIONS. Section 3(a) of the Lacey Act Amendments of 1981 is amended to include provisions regarding the import, export, transport, sale, acquisition, or possession of prohibited wildlife species in interstate or foreign commerce. In paragraph (5), the amendment includes striking ``(1) through (3)'' and inserting ``(1) through (4)''. SEC. 5. NONAPPLICABILITY OF OFFENSES. In General, Section 3(e) of the Lacey Act Amendments of 1981 is amended to exempt certain activities related to prohibited wildlife species under specific regulations. This includes requirements for institutions accredited by the Association of Zoos and Aquariums (AZA) or certified facilities coordinating with an AZA Species Survival Plan for breeding threatened or endangered species. The Lacey Act Amendments of 1981 are amended to exempt activities related to prohibited wildlife species under specific regulations, including restrictions on off-site transportation and display of animals. Possession of prohibited wildlife species born before a certain date must be registered within 180 days of implementing regulations. This includes providing inappropriate veterinary care or handling that causes stress or trauma to the species or poses a threat to public safety. The Lacey Act Amendments of 1981 are being updated to include civil and criminal penalties for violations. Civil penalties are amended to include subsection (a)(4) and subsection (d), while criminal penalties are amended to include knowingly violating section 3(a)(4) and due care violations. SEC. 7 addresses forfeiture. Section 5(a) of the Lacey Act Amendments of 1981 is amended to include purchasing, breeding, or possessing wildlife, and expands the scope of prohibited activities to include importation, exportation, transportation, sale, receipt, acquisition, and intent to engage in these activities.
